THE PAEY MERCURY.

MONDAY, -DECEMIBER 24. 1923. - CHRISTMA STIDE .

One of the most pleasant fealarcs cf Christmastide is -that it offers a brief respite from the toil: common to humanity - and -'-creates An atmos phere totally different to any other

season of the year. A special season 'Of rejoicing from time Immemorial seems to have ' prevailed among the peoples, of the earth, a period of feasting and pleasure to celebrate a national event - or" national customs, 'With Europeans the festival is as sociated With' the 'Christian. Church, observed 4n honor of -the birth of Jesus Christ Whose message was that peace and goodwill should reign amongst1 men. The Christian- festi val, however,' was not original, but merely a diversion, to turn the minds of the early Christians , from the heathen "festivals prevalent at the time that .were degrading In many details. The Saturnalia, -the festi val of " Saturn; was a great national event with the Romans. It was celebrated in tbe third week in De cember, and lasted from five to 'seven -'days,4 during which the, schools were closed, no war was declared or battle -fought, distinctions of rank .were- set aside, and tbe utmost free dom of speech was allowed. Gamb ling, otherwise illegal, was allowed. .All classes exchanged gifts, candles wire burnt and -fires kindled— Eng lishmen still have the Yule Log . or Christmas Block — and 1 the people give themselves up to general joy and mirth. With the subs/ituiion of Christianity for heathenism the ' ne cessity of destroying 'the1. worst feat ures of this festival became obvious, and tbe date of the Nativity was chosen by the Christians' -for doing so. There is no certainty about the 26th of December being the precise date of Christ's birth. Authorities mostly , agree that it could not have taken place at that time of the year, and (this ' . strengthens the opinion that the Christian festival was in tended to supplant' the Saturnalia already mentioned, ' which was- held In December. . There need be no time wasted on -this point, however, for, as one writer states, communi ties whi'ch observe the day lay more stress. on the memory of the event it represents than on the date fixed for the celebration . Christmas is . in dubitably associated with .festivities common to birthday celebrations . It is a period of rejoicing, more or leas unrestrained, -according to the tem perament of ' the, individual or 'com munity. The ancient Saturnalia dif fers -from YuletiiJe only in that it was disfigured by tbe vice' that; was associated with heathen celebrations. Tho proceedings of the festival cS Satum .read like the present-day jChristjnas 'festival,, /We;' read; /that

"The /schools were closed. All classes exchanged gifts, the common est being wax tapers and clay dolls; these dolls were - given to children, and the makers of them held a . re gular fair at the time," That sounds like Christmas shopping of the pre sent day, does it -not? Yet it was practiced yearg before the Nativity, the event Christians now celebrate annually, and shows there always has been good in mankind, that men -felt it desirable to have a season of goodwill, of rest from the cares and struggles of daily life "when wars should not be declared or battles fought," and, if more prominence is given to this ancient spirit' to-day, if the.spirit of tolerance and a wider view of life is taken -than, in 'the "dark ages/ who will doubt but that it marks the gradual fulfilment of the prophetic angelic songburst heard by .shepherds, '.'Glory to God : In the hjghest, and on earth peace, good will toward, men," Wie join in the salutation .that is offered everywhere at th@ present tiriie; and wish our readers, . . ..laLI /A . iMeriy. Any slump in trade that affects our primary products first hits the producer, and-'-after that the commun ity at large.. Some times it is re-

ported that the cattle men are hit, or the- sheep men, the wheat grower, dairymen, oit sugar, grower. (These primary producers at .varying times -r-lueklly it seldom happens, that they all suffer at the same time — are badly affected by weather conditions, the markets, or 'something else. No class of producer suffers alone at any time, for when their business is depressed scores of other people, workers, -busi ness men -and shippers, suffer also. The. community, therefore, is direct ly .concerned- in tho welfare of every primary produict-'"in . tho same sense almost as a shareholder is in a com pany, or at least members are in any co-operative concern. At "the present time cattle producers are suffering from ia very ser luus de pression j'n tile demand for stock. These conditions are somewhat un usual and therefore could not be foreseen. Weather Conditions have on the whole been favorable for a long- time,1 and nothing lias interven ed to put a check on icattle- raising on this side " of-, the world. Tho trouble is due chiefly -to the export trade. For years past Queensland lias depended upon its (export trade for the disposal of its surplus supply. There was always the London market to fall back upon and prior to the war at least the meat companies felt that that -market could be used profit ably to relieve any congestion o£ supplies at this -end. This outlet is no longer open to Australia, as iu pre-war days. 'South America is now a formidable opponent of Australia inasmuch as it- can. -supply /most of tho foreign jmeat required -by .England, and is able to send it across in a chilled state in four -weeks, whereas Australia requires four months to land its beef in London, and it has to be frozen. The -market prefers chilled meat.' It is also stated that South American beef is marketed in a more excellent condition than the Australian. Another disadvantage that Australia suffers; from is that frozen meat is sent oyer in the second half of tlie year, when home grown beef is plentiful. The -bulk of the Australian' shipments arrive in Eng land between July and December. Another drawback in-,tjie competition -between South America and Austra? lia is the difference in the cost of production. South American rates are much lower, than the Australian standard, ;and '.'the combination of cheaper rates in tlie pastures, in the killing yards, and in. the shipment of beef to London tells heavily against Australia. As (showing tlie effect of - present conditions;' upon . the Rattle industry we ' might qucSte from the last "annual report of the Queensland Xatioual Pastoral Company, which states: "During tlie year we sold 9222 head' of cattle, -practically all fat bullocks, for £40,533, an average cf £4/7, -110 per head, against 10.35S -head for £109;53G for the preceding year, an average of £10/11/7, and for 1920 we sold 99911 at an average of £13/3/9 per head. These figures speak for themselves, and it is easily understandable that no profit can be made out ofxattle under pre sent-day conditions, anil until there is a decided general improvement in stock values. On the other hand, wool selling conditions were as good as one could wish - and compensated in a measure for the low meat prices and droughty conditions under which -w-e have had to labor: Since 1920

our cattle sales have dropped £S/1E/11 per head, and £91,241 in volume." As there is no prospect of ail improvement taking place with out special assistance, it is claimed that, Britain should give preference to British grown foodstuffs a-s against the produce of such cheap foreign countries as South America. In Eng land, however, there is the same ele ment that we have in Victoria, which talks loudly in support of Empire trade but when it comes to fostering that trade' in; the only pos sible way they use all their influence tp prevent the Government from doing if! English freetraders want cheap foodstuffs just the same as Victorians want cheap sugar, -and despite their patriotic protestations they do not care whether it is produced by black or foreign labor, (as long (as tfliey get it. Unless Great Britain does something practical in the . direction of encouraging supplies of foodstuffs from within the Empire sources of production must be curtailed, as is now threatening in the case of the cattle industry. ....

YORK PENINSULA EXPEDITION.

: captain wilkin's experience. . IPRAM.I' THROUGH TRACKLESS HUSH.

v (Special to; "Daily Mercury.")

IV 1 „ In this article Captain Wilkins continues tlio story of, his expe dition to York Peninsula in search of ' fauna for the British M.useum. lie made a trip overland to the M orcton telegraph station, in com pany with an aborigine; but failed to see much animal or bird life. Ho gives a glimpse of aboriginal customs, and an interesting nccount of a little-known part of the. far North.

Six weeks spent hunting in the vicinity of Cape Grenville fuilcd greatly to increase our collection of mammals for the British Museum. A good fo>v birds were collected but of the few species of large mammals known to exist in thut aroa we saw but' throe or four individuals, and these were so elusive that we seldom had more than a glimpse of them as they dashed away through the bush. Nntives who had lived there all their lives told us that they seldom suw an animal, and did not depend on them at all for food. Sometimes the natives are short of food, but this, need never happen if they cared to cultivate potatoeV or, plant coconnuts oh the many suitable benches along the coast. A Trip Overland. The absence of animals in the Cape Grenville district made it necessary for me to travel inland and south to dis cover, if possible, just where the game- inhabited country was to be found. So. when the launch arrived to convey us back to Thursday Island, the rest of the expedition went on board, and I set out for Moreton telegraph station, on the, western side of the Great Di- 1 viding Range. It was necessary to walk : and carry 's pack for the first stage of the journey, and the load was to be reduced to a mimimum. Johnnie, a native, was to go with me as guide. In the hurry to get the party away on the launch, everything was bundled on board, and the serviceable eating and cooking utensils went with them, and when I came to pack my gear I found that I should have to make-shift with one or two old cans and a sheath- kni£e- i! This, of- course, was no unsurmount- able difficulty, but for a white man lo be without knife, fork, plate, and spoon at meals in front of a native, is to lose all: dignity from the native's point of view, and he is treated thereafter with studied contempt or 'ignored. These conditions pleased me rather than .otherwise, for the dignity that needs to be upheld by .the dexterous use of table utensils may well be foregone for the opportunity to study the natives' natural 'behaviour and not his acquired company manners that are adopted from the white' men. Johnnie was no excep tion to the rule, and showed plainly his opinion of me after our first meal to gether. : Stuck in the Mud. O.ur camp had been on the south side of the Olive River, and from there we struck out in a west-by-northerly course across the sandy tree-covered River that runs right up to the foot, of the Dividing Range. Beyond the hills towards a branch of the Olive : hills near the coast is a stretch of flat, swlunpy. ground, overgrown with low trees and pandanus palms. We skirted 'most' of the wetter .patches, but there was one, several ' miles long, but not ' very wide, that Johnnie ele.c- . ted to cross. This was the only bad patch on the route, so he said, and here the mud was "too much, plenty soft, but suppose takem off -boot's, you cross all right." With a pack of some GO pounds, and my own heavy weight, I sank deeper and deeper at each step, in ground that joiin.nie walked over with com parative ease. The . more I hurried the deeper I wont, and we presently came to a spot that seemed bottom less. v ' ' Unable to. extract my feet, I was slowly sinking; "and throwing my pack ahead, and leaning as far forward as 'possible, waited in that position until 'Johnnie could pave the way with bro ken bushes, over which I crawled to the harder ground beyond.' We .were a sorry spectacle before we reached the well-grassed ground on the other side of the swamp. A Blaekts Camp. After a two hours' yyplk \ye came t.o. the Olive River, a,nd enjoyed a bath and a swim, and, crossing the stream, we followed its northern bank until 'reaching a native camping place. There were four families of natives here, and they were all suffering from the same type of- cold that Johnnie had, and which, they said, they bad contyactifd' from other pp. ti.ves further inland. They had beep ;too iib Ld hunt for 'food during the last two or three days, so they said, but this was probably a story told to affect my expected generosity. 'I hud very little m.pt'e food than.. Aye

needed for our journey, so I copld .not: 'spare them much. One of the men, the murderer, who had killed >a ;'':ncdi- cine man," who' hack 'operated, .unsuc cessfully on , a boy, '/ and of whonv we had heard so much, volunteered to ac company me' on tho nyo.ijrow,' nnd_ help me carry the pack ovo'r- the; -range, but . during, the - night he had. .been Aolfl of tji.e flour,, tea, uqjl .sugar.tjiat I .tittil .left pnv tho 'beach fqr J ohnnie; and -in ' >tlie morning , the man ;decidcd.'Jthat lie would . rather go, to .the', beaoh and. t'm.ind" tins food than carry my pack to Moreton. Johnnfe, ho.wo.vei;, - stuch .to his bargain, ' altliough lie was suffering from a bad

cold. I do not know if he got back . in time to share the food he had earned, but as I loaded him'' up with provisions and tobacco at Moreton,- he probably would not hurry. - Error on the Map. We kept to tV>e north of Hie main brunch of the Olive- River, for about 20 miles, travelling in a westerly, di rection, and crossing the 'position marked on the chart, ris the upper reuches of the Macmillan River. It seems that in d, rawing the features of 1 this area, tlrp: .eurtographer has joined, the branches of the Oliye Riyer to the, main stream of the Macmillan, while in reality the Macmillan docs . not come .nearly go far south. ' Tho country we crossed is com paratively' low and undulating, and is the southern end of a wide 'depres sion between t(ie Richardson and the Great Dividing Range. The surface is snndy .,unti) the Main Range is reached, and then we found coarse sandstone and ironstone boulders, with a little red soil here and there. The timber was mostly ti-tree and bloodwood, but a few "gums" were seen neartlie bank of the river. . During the greater part of the jour ney we were in open country, where the grnss hnd been" a few days before three or four fc'et high,' but whieli had now disappeared in the huge fires that had swept the country for miles. An occasional patch of grass had escaped, but Johnnie never failed! to drop a match into this as we passed, arid a trail of smoke' and roaring flames went off to leeward. In these districts, and about the time of the year, the grass is burnt off, annually, and in a few weeks, o.ven without any rain, the shoots nppear, and soon the blackened ground is covered with a waving mass of green. ' We ascended the range by the river valley, and on either, side were! sand stone ridges. Johnnie pointed south to a 'round-topped peuk, and' said, '.'Plenty lie too much gold stop there:" He de clared that no white man. -.had seen it,' but I am led to believe that this is a stock story with the natives; Absence of Life. So far we bad seen no , animals, and birds were just as scarce as they were near he coast. One conspicuous addi tion to their number was the southern jackass, whose raucous laugh;ter we had not heard for several weeks, its place being taken by the curious squawkings of the brightof-plumaged northern bird. It was not until passing inland for oyer 20 miles that I heard' the familiar laugh ing sound, and it was comparatively rare in all districts visited in York Peninsula. We camped at the foot of a steep hill that topped the range, and next morning began ;the ascent. Although our altitude was never, high, it seemed that- we climbed , to the highest part of the. r.idgc, avoiding, the lower passes. The reason for this was .clear when ive Reached the .summit and coulil sen through the tree tops that we had skirted many patches of thick scrub, and ,by fpHojving; ,fhe , top ..'of the ridge we would be able ' to keep in ' well- grassed country most of- the way. Slowly descending,, we came to a bet ter class of soil, and soon found traces of animal life; First a few tracks of kangaroos were "seen, and .then those of ' wallabies, and towards the foot : of the j range we found traces of. horses and I cattle. " , v | A Changing Place. We had walked over 20 miles that day, and when we were nearing Moreton telegraph station we came to a- good- sized pool of water , in which I decided' to bathe and then discard my clothes, that had been worn threadbare in the struggles through the !' bush and blackened with soot ol! forest fires. This pool had been the meeting place, my guide told me, of the natives in early days. Many corroborees had taken place there, and it was there the forces gathered to attack the telegraph sta tion, not so many years ago. It seemed that I was not tho first white man to rest beside this pool and change clothes before approaching such civilisation .as. the- -lonely outpost tele-' graph station affords; -Aronnd'-tho pool were heaps of . clothes 4in all stages, of. decay — old i mole' skins,'- tw.oe.ds,' hnd serges, and shirts of many colors, each nr.ticle. worn threadbare o.r torn to rib- , bons; Boots ivith uppers ' slashed, and soles still stout, and;; others with hardly a' sign' of solo- remaining, told tales of weary, aching feet... These heaps of mouldering clothes" suggested tales of various adventures; some . of them ,\vai)de.j;ipg. prppqtl . the continent to disappear, into .the--. Western ! ..Gulf country, never to be Ijcard pf -agiuh— for the natives' of 'thpt area; are. -a, till treacherous— of ' union agitators patrol ling outba.ck : stations, .gpld -speksrs, 'starved out pud seeking aid;, -gaol-- breaking., aborigines, discarding shirt and ' trousers fop ithe mp.re scanty garb ofi' the ("bush" and perhaps ..eyeji the discards., of a .white woman ; -who is known to have worked her way along the Peninsula .to Thurpdpy Island. " i was tempted-; to stop 'hnd conjure . Ptc.ture.s .beside that pool, but the sup .was already ...tinging . th,e gypen-louvod . trees' Awith,;. gold '.and silhouetting the- tall, dry trunks.' of ; the older, timber, so I_ .moved on- and received" a hearty -, greeting from the officers at the. tele graph station. CAPE YORK EXPEDITION. ,

MORETON TELEGRAPH STATION ARSENAL. CAMP INVADED BV FROGS.

(Special to "Daily Mercury.")

,'In his second article on his journey in York Peninsula, Captain Wilkinsi recalls conditions in . the early days of the telegraph station, when protective means had: to be tak'en against- hostile natives. He dcscribosvfhe"- peninsula as a pines for the white man, with very grout economic possibilities. . ,

i i . - Most of the telegraph stations on the Cape York — LaUra : line are built on similar lines to the Morcton station, where I had afrivod with "Johnnie"— a seven-roomed house, in the form of a hollow square, A veranda! runs com pletely round the inside and on two sides of the outor and on the corners are iron battlements with loopholes. On £ the walls hang old Martini-Henry rifles and heavy revolvers, but these weapons are not needed in thu service now, aiid ar only moved' for periodical cleanings. The natives arc more easily' a nd- su pee s s f u 1 1 y subdued to-day by the threiit .to cut off their supply of tobacco, than by. the use of firearms or force. THlittle telegraph instrument is' set h li -on eo ft he rooms through which the single wire . runs and passes out and along the .centre of a narrow clearing 'that u-iS&hetl1' as far as the eye can see -r-a ribbon of dry, brown grass between the: dark green tree tops. This clear ing, the handiwork of man, is strikingly impressive when i it is met with- after spending several months in virgin scrubs. For several days, with natives as companions, I hunted in the vicinity ofMoroton, but -failed to discover any animals, and then, through the kind ness of one known as "Friday," I was able to put my pack ' on a horse and ride' another on,, my way to Merluna State station.:,?.,:;, ; ; Moreton 'telegraph station is on the north 'bank V 'of (he Batavia River, --so we crossed the stream that is now not more than waist-deep, but which in flood tinjes spills over,the banks some 50 odd feet high, and swamps the neighboring country. The country south of the Ba tavia River carries much better feed for 'sto'ek thRii any 'wo had seen in the Northy and' the conditions improved as we went South, The action "Of burning the grasses an nually, as practised in the far north, produces course, hard food for . the greater part of the year, and it- seems that a great deal might be done by the introduction of finer herbs and grasses suited to- Vhe so'l and climate. Frog-Infestcil, . We camped at the crossing at Lydia Creek. Frog Swamp would be a suit able name for the place, for in -the even ing, as wis sat by the' fire at supper, small green frogs hopped in countless numbers alt about us. Scores went into the re, and our billycan and cups of tea received their share. It would have been useless to throw the tea away; since the next boiling would have been served in a simi.lar manner, so we sipped, our soupy beverage as stoically as pos sible.: I have 'eaten frogs' legs in France, and found them tasty, but the thought of drinking frog was certainly nob pleasant, and we went to bed rather thirsty that night. Even under our blankets we were not free fr.u the pests, , and several times I was awakened by a slimy body alighting heavily on my face. I had. left my mosquito net covering on the coast, and on a later oc casion , suffered because of its absence. A nocturnal spider bit me on the- eyelid as I lay asleep one night, and by the morning my Oye was so swollen that I could not , see. It remained Tike this for two -days, but the swelling eventu ally went down, and I suffered no other ill effects;. . -. Native Diffidence, From Lydia Creek we went to (several) (other water cours'es, but in no place were mammals plentiful. A few tracks could be seen, and an oc casional marsupial, but they were all exceptionally timid. It was not until we reached the home paddocks of tlie station .that we found the animals and birds- more plentiful. At Merluna sta-. tion iwe received every kindness, and I was able to collect a few specimens. I procured two horses and a native guide at Merluna, and expected to be able to' induce the other natives to hunt and bring in specimens to the camp. This they failed to do, and the fact that I had not been able to get a single specimen from the natives puzzled me, until oho day, towards the end of my trip, my guide confessed that the "bush" natives would not hunt for. , me; because, although I had offered them any amount of money and to bacco, they hid heard that I .wanted tiio skins and(. skeletons of everything, and ' when ' I had 'secured all the walla bies and opossums I wanted, I would take the skin 'and , bones of several natives. "By cripos," . ho said, "me pfeller no want'em skin and bones be- ; ianga me go long that place England, too tguchem cold- that country!" -Indifferent Mining. From Merluna we ' passed through Mcin to the |g6ldfields. The , "dig gings" at this .-place are no doubt-' typical of many.'hth'ors in Australia— a few old prospectors sink their shafts working alono and zealously', guarding the secret of their wealth. They, live fairly wcil for 'bush" conditions, and are extrem'ely hospitable and confiding to strangers, but 'before one is allowed to view their "dut" bags that are con cealed in various ' corners of their hum pies or descend, their shafts, one is sworn to secrecy .V' It was under these conditions that I was- allowed to in spect several workings/' and the most

.- 1 < : that, I can say is that tiio .men arc satisfied to work them. ' , ,In recrossing the Batavia Riybr I had roachcd the granite country. that stretches to the coast, . and ,t pxtends south from the Pascoe Riverv .h'A hills and ranges from there tHrodgh Tin Creek to Coen offered mora, pleas ing aspects than did the sandy . ridges further north. Coen is now li sorry- looking township, . with few inhabitants, and few signs of even remote pros perity. The one hotel, kept by most obliging people, has been constructed from the -ruins of iron houses. Paint- .has covered most of the rust, but in the walls of ' the room I occupied, many h(oles are visible. . These nail holes were the means of giving me a shock in the early hours of the morning, and .had it not been for the fact that I am an abstainer, I might have attributed the phenomenon I saw to other sources. I wakened just -after duylight, and. before mo on the wall I saw ton shjadowy witches leaping wildly, and brandishing a broom, while an elon gated mammal streaked in front. My sleep-lulled brain wns stnrtled until I heard the shouts, and realised that tbo nail-Koles in the wall had converted the room into a camera abscura, and by the pin-hole photographic method I was seeing ah animated shadowgraph, mul tiplied by the number of holes, of an old nntive woman chasing a dog that -had stolen the breakfast steak from the kitchen table. Days on the Coast. At Coen I was faced with the long and somewhat uninteresting ride to Laura, and then to Cooktown by train, but by. good fortune I heard that it might be possible to catch a boat pass ing (Flinders Island, and decided to ride to Port Stewart, and by arrange ment with the owner of a fleet ' of beche-d'e-nier "fishing" boats, get put on board. I hurried towards the coast, crossing the Great Dividing Range again wiith its granite outcrops and round-topped hills, and then, across the broad flat plain to Port Stewart. At Port. Stewart 1 saw more marsupials in a two hours' ride than I had seen in the two and a half months spent in the districts further north. I reached the coast just in time t board a ketch n charge of "Hughie" Giblet, an old- identity, who has been along that coast and on the Peninsula for over 20 years. I had two -days to wait for the steamer, and as the guest of Mr. Giblet I spent them profitably in sailing along the coast and hunting. We camped ashore- one night, and. received an official. visit from King Fred (aborigine), of Lloyd's Bay, and several neighboring districts. King Fred was dressed in khaki shirt, trousers, and -wore on liis head a towel rolled . and twisted to form a crown. Suspended from a chain slung round his neck was a crescent-shaped brass- plate proclaiming the area of his do- 'minions and his native name and tot'em. Ke introduced me . to his followers, and suggested that I reward them' with- -to bacco. He granted me permission- to hunt through all his country, - -and offered to send his retinue to:. .-hunt with me next -day, and that day's hunting .was the most -successful I had during my. stay on York Peninsula, North for- the -Whites,. The conditions, as I found them on York Peninsula, are most surprising. The vegetation oh the mainland does not >n any way resemble that found in other tropical., lands in similar lati tudes; in fact, it can hardly be called ,a- "tropical",' condition at all. Few tropical fruits' wore found, and very few brilliant flowers or birds were seen, but otherwise there. are all the delights -of the. tropics without the "muggy" weather, fevers, and evils that tha word "tropical" suggests to those who have travelled in some older countries. Dense scrubs are confined to small areas, and cannot be compared with the jungles of other countries as obstacles in the way of travel. Disease and posts, and especially troublesome insect life, are, by comparison, extremely rare, and the climate, at least during June, July, and August, is as delightful as the best of seasons on the Riviera/ Its. scenery is, perhaps, not sufficiently' attractive to justify a tourist's trip, but the coun try from the Batavia and Pascoe Rivers; south, is rich in pastoral lands, and is a likely field for mineral, discoveries. Many of the beaches were well suited for cocoanut plantations and the grow ing of- "catch" crops of vegetables and bananas. In the valleys near the coast and) on ItN© islands such /as Hick's Island, where a plantation is already in existence, .it is possible to. grow muny of-- the spices and products that have now to be imported to Australia, . Rice, cotton, tea, coffee, pepper, and dates might be grown in abundance, and nutmegs, camphor, cinnamon, cocaine, quassia, croton, and other, valuable things might.be produced in quantity if the population of Australia could sup port those industries. More people with capital are needed, and a satisfactory solution of the labor problem, whether it lies in the employment of white or black. The people who say that tropi cal Australia is not a white man's country, have not experienced the de lightful weather conditions' we found on York Peninsula.

articleText:
SYBIL CREEK,

(From Our Correspondent.)

Drought conditions still prevail, and although we had a few Barcoo thunder storms, which gave a little rain, the position is daily growing more desolate. Heavy rain clouds bank up daily, but high winds soon scatter them. The stock are in a deplorable condition; it

is to be hoped rain will soon eventu- ate, if for nothing else but to bring feed to these helpless beasts. The young cane looks green, but there is no growth. Farmers ore still doggedly slogging away in hopes of a change in the sea- son. Mr. Geo. Hoi has cleared a nice piece of scrub on the roadside near the creek and planted same. , It. is remark able how quickly - the cane came through despite the dry season. The new settlement, on Beatrice t Creek' is proceeding npaco. In conversation/with Mr. George Heritage, one .' of the "Digger" farmers, he informed me that the young plant .cane, is looking good, and clearing is going on apace. He ex tended me an invitation to visit the lo cality, and I ' intend to do so shortly. Cnttle Creek mill intends putting a tramway out' to this' locality ; they are to be helped in the matter by the farm ers.' So much for co-operation. Those interested are to bo complimented on pushing our district ahead. Health matters are not the best, in our little community. . Miss Fanny Clausen, daughtur, of Mr. .Jas. Clausen, was taken suddenly ill quite recently, . and- for a time was in a serious condi tion, She was removed to. a private' hospital in Mackay, and report says she is now progressing well. .'Mr. T. Linth- waite, senr., is in a serious condition in the District Hospital. .Many chil dren have been- ill with a form of gas tritis. There is one thing, Mi-. Editor, the public think is not right in this' connection, that dead bodies of cattle should bo allowed to lie by the roadside and pollute the air and otherwise spread . contagion. ' Another matter for concern is the fruit which is sold to countrysid'ers. Apples, for instance, should be exam ined and sold -as lit for consumption. A story goes the round here that one local resident purchased a case of apples and the only use he could put them to was to throw same at stray fowls or dogs. It is said that 'even the dog smiled,. and the fowls passed them by. . The local School had a gala day on. Snturday .last, when the breaking-rip festivities were hold. A' largo crowd of parents . and visitors attended, and a pleasant afternoon was/ spent ; in: sports and games: The lpmics' commit tee, consisting of Mesmes Hansen, A. Burns, G. Burns, 0. Benson, B. J. Langford, W. Burns, and F. Linthwaitc, provided refreshments, and the children did the rest.. At were . assembled ; in the school-room by the -teacher,' Mr. M, A. MeColl. The chairman, Mr. E. Hansen, explained that as the Teachers' Union regarded prize- giving as unprofessional conduct, the committee had decided to give each child a book us a gift. Each child was then presented with a handsome book as some recognition from the public.-, Mr. Hansen thanked the public for their assistance. He also thanked the teacher for .the interest he had taken in the children .at all .'times in' organising various forms of- amusement to: brighten ' "their li ve Tfi nil ep en <1 eii t 'of""scTiool work . Mr. : McColl replied . arid ': thanked the chairman for tlie kind remarks. -He- ' said that the Union had laid down cer tain rules, and it was his intention to try and: carry, them out. It was no use having rules if people wore allowed to ignore, th'emu. Such procedure- was only a. farce. , He also thanked : the ladies for ..helping .-him during;, the year with the various -social functions for the children'. Cheers were ..given for the teacher,'- ladies and gentlemen, and all who' assisted. A dance was held at night and Was thoroughly enjoyed- by- young :an force' to have a good time.; At the in vitation ' of the committee and teacher, the public were invited to; a tennis evening on the following day. A couple of teams wore selected. "' Mr; ; Jack Cprran . captained the Thistles and Mr. Sam McGimpsey the Shamrocks. Some good play was witnessed. The Sham rocks were victorious by four games. Dainty refreshments were served. A pretty, wedding was celebrated on Saturday, last,, when Miss Eileen Linth- waite- wap -married to Mr. Dave. Cook. We '.wish,' the happy couple long life and heaps of luck. I wish the "Mercury" arid staff the compliments of the festive season.
